column2: Murman, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I see a few negative reviews for this medication.  I think that the posters of the negative reviews do not understand that this drug is administered to prevent uric acid build up and prevent FUTURE acute gout attacks.  If you are already having an acute attack this medication will be administered after the acute attack has occurred and been treated with an NSAID or similar medication that treats the swelling/Pain and lowers the high uric acid causing your current attack.  If allopurinol is administered during an acute gout attack it can cause the attack to get worse before getting better.  Hence using an NSAID or similar drug during an acute attack. This is a long term drug that your doctor will prescribe based on the frequency/severeness of your acute attacks.  It should be taken until your Dr. tells you to take something as a replacement.  DO NOT stop taking this medication just because you have not had an attack for a while.  The reason you have not had an attack is the Allopurinol.Make sure to have your blood tested yearly at your Yearly Physical exam for Uric Acid, Kidney, Liver Function, and whatever else your Dr. wants to check so he can adjust the dose and make sure you do not have any other underlying problems.I have tried adjusting diet instead of taking allopurinol but both times I have been in bed for a week looking at my swollen aching foot/feet wondering why I would try and eliminate Beer, Red Wine, Red Meat, Shellfish, and all the other great tasting food/beverages instead of just taking allopurinol once a day for the rest of my life.Hope this helps.

I thought after the first one, it was caused by eating crab meat but my blood was tested for allergies to seafood and found negative. I did have a few beers a couple of days before the attack and had a few beers before this last attack. So, it would appear drinking beer is what is triggering my attacks. So, although the med reduces my chances of getting an attack, it hasn't eliminated them completely.

column9: Diagnosed with gout last year after months of excruciating pain so bad I could not put feet on floor or stand sheet to touch them. Finally increased dose to 600mg daily and finally pain free. Can eat normally and walk without pain in toes and feet. Pain in elbows also gone. Could not walk last year at this time, finally at high enough dose to keep me pain free. No issues with medication so far.

column9: I had severe allergic reaction to this medication and almost died. I broke out in a horrible rash all over my body, the worst the Dr's had seen, my kidneys almost shut down, I was throwing up, nauseated and had a high fever. Blood pressure went dangerously low and I am still on Medrol and Benadryl to treat the reaction. It is slowly moving out my hands and feet but it has left what my Dr. is calling 3rd degree type burns all over my body and I am peeling but still lobster red. I understand that not many people are allergic to this drug but if you start getting nauseated or get a rash that starts out small please seek the advice of your healthcare advisor. I let mine go too long and almost died.

column2: Meech, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: 6 years ago, I was having about 1 gout attack a month in my feet and ankles, which would last for up to 2 weeks. The attacks were so bad I would end up on the floor in tears. I've broken many bones and had sprains due to my athletic lifestyle. The gout pain is/was by far was the most painful of anything I've experienced. I started on 100 mg of Allopurinol for 2 months, but the attacks still came. My doctor bumped it up to 300 mg and then about 6 weeks later, I realized my feet and fingers felt great. I have not had a SINGLE attack since. I do, on occasion, feel the beginnings of an attack from time to time. But if I drink a lot of water, about 32 oz in one hour, the pain would slowly go away. That is BY FAR better than a full-blown attack like I used to have. I take the meds religiously during lunch everyday and rarely forget. After experincing the pain I did, I wouldn't dare forget! This drug works great, I think the only real negative side effects I've had is nausea if I take it on an empty stomach or with little food, and a small headache if I don't drink enough water. Water consumption is very important when taking Allopurinol. Luckily for me, I love the taste of water. My advice for those just starting the meds, be patient and drink water constantly. Doesn't have to be a lot of water each time, just enough to wet your whistle each time. There will come the day when you will suddenly say, "Hey! I haven't had an attack since ..." Good luck!
